user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_fdset2:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_get_fdset2 (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                fd_set *read_fd_set,
                fd_set *write_fd_set,
                fd_set *except_fd_set,
                MHD_socket *max_fd,
                unsigned int fd_setsize)
{
  if ( (NULL == daemon) ||
       (NULL == read_fd_set) ||
       (NULL == write_fd_set) ||
       MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon) ||
       MHD_D_IS_USING_POLL_ (daemon))
    return MHD_NO;

#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  if (NULL == except_fd_set)
  {
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("MHD_get_fdset2() called with except_fd_set "
                 "set to NULL. Such behavior is unsupported.\n"));
  }
#endif

#ifdef HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE
  if (0 == fd_setsize)
    return MHD_NO;
  else if (((unsigned int) INT_MAX) < fd_setsize)
    fd_setsize = (unsigned int) INT_MAX;
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  else if (daemon->fdset_size > ((int) fd_setsize))
  {
    if (daemon->fdset_size_set_by_app)
    {
      MHD_DLOG (daemon,
                _ ("%s() called with fd_setsize (%u) " \
                   "less than value set by MHD_OPTION_APP_FD_SETSIZE (%d). " \
                   "Some socket FDs may be not processed. " \
                   "Use MHD_OPTION_APP_FD_SETSIZE with the correct value.\n"),
                "MHD_get_fdset2", fd_setsize, daemon->fdset_size);
    }
    else
    {
      MHD_DLOG (daemon,
                _ ("%s() called with fd_setsize (%u) " \
                   "less than FD_SETSIZE used by MHD (%d). " \
                   "Some socket FDs may be not processed. " \
                   "Consider using MHD_OPTION_APP_FD_SETSIZE option.\n"),
                "MHD_get_fdset2", fd_setsize, daemon->fdset_size);
    }
  }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
#else  /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */
  if (((unsigned int) FD_SETSIZE) > fd_setsize)
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("%s() called with fd_setsize (%u) " \
                 "less than fixed FD_SETSIZE value (%d) used on the " \
                 "platform.\n"),
              "MHD_get_fdset2", fd_setsize, (int) FD_SETSIZE);
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
    return MHD_NO;
  }
  fd_setsize = (int) FD_SETSIZE; /* Help compiler to optimise */
#endif /* ! HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE */

#ifdef EPOLL_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_ (daemon))
  {
    if (daemon->shutdown)
      return MHD_YES;

    /* we're in epoll mode, use the epoll FD as a stand-in for
       the entire event set */

    return MHD_add_to_fd_set_ (daemon->epoll_fd,
                               read_fd_set,
                               max_fd,
                               (int) fd_setsize) ? MHD_YES : MHD_NO;
  }
#endif

  return internal_get_fdset2 (daemon,
                              read_fd_set,
                              write_fd_set,
                              except_fd_set,
                              max_fd,
                              (int) fd_setsize);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_get_fdset2:
#define MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_(d) (0!=(d->options&(MHD_USE_INTERNAL_POLLING_THREAD)))
...
#define MHD_D_IS_USING_POLL_(d) (0!=((d)->options&MHD_USE_POLL))
...
#define MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_(d) (0!=((d)->options&MHD_USE_EPOLL))
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No controlling expressions in the provided function are invariant. Each if/else/conditional depends on runtime values (function parameters, daemon->members, or the result of function/macro evaluations):
- The initial compound if tests daemon, fd_set pointers, and macros that expand to checks on daemon->options (runtime). These are not compile-time constants.
- fd_setsize checks compare the parameter against constants (0, INT_MAX, FD_SETSIZE) — these expressions are not invariant because they depend on the fd_setsize argument.
- The EPOLL_SUPPORT branch is enabled/disabled by a preprocessor macro (not a C controlling expression); the runtime if inside that block tests daemon->options or daemon->shutdown.
- The ternary used on return evaluates the result of a function call — not an invariant.
- There are no loops with constant controlling expressions; the listed MISRA exceptions (infinite loops or the specific do-while constant-false case) do not apply here.
Preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef ...) are not governed by MISRA Rule 14.3 (they are not C-level controlling expressions). Therefore no code fragments require further investigation under Rule 14.3.
